qas.question: In what forms of government are leaders not held to the same laws as ordinary citizens?
According to the rule of law, who must obey the laws?
What are governments called that are created with the rule of law in mind?
What happens to the rule of law if a government does not have an effective system for maintenance and restoration?
For what reasons might democratic societies not follow the rule of law?

answers.text: neglect or ignorance of the law

qas.question: According to rule of law who is not subject to the law?
Who was held above the law in a nomocracy?

plausible_answers.text: Lack of the rule of law

qas.question: What is often found in dictatorships but not democracies

plausible_answers.text: neglect or ignorance of the law

qas.question: What causes rule of law to decay in a dictatorship?

context: Rule of law implies that <a1_0>every citizen<a1_0/> is subject to the law, including <b5_0>law makers<b5_0/> themselves. In this sense, it stands in contrast to an <a0_0>autocracy, dictatorship, or oligarchy<a0_0/> where the <b6_0>rulers<b6_0/> are held above the law. <b7_0>Lack of the rule of law<b7_0/> can be found in both democracies and dictatorships, for example because of <a4_0><b8_0>neglect or ignorance of the law<b8_0/><a4_0/>, and the rule of law is more apt to <a3_0>decay<a3_0/> if a government has insufficient corrective mechanisms for restoring it. Government based upon the rule of law is called <a2_0>nomocracy<a2_0/>.
